newsitem.title: UK: Forties, Oseberg crude benefit from gas oil rally.
newsitem.headline: Forties, Oseberg crude benefit from gas oil rally.

text.p: North Sea crude markets were buoyed up by extremely strong refining margins, particularly for gas oil-rich grades like Oseberg and Forties, and sentiment remained strong on Thursday despite a fall-off in activity after Wednesday's frantic exchanges.

Six million barrels of North Sea crude changed hands at mostly strenthening premiums on Wednesday, but a cargo of sour Flotta sold on Thursday at Dated Brent -57.5 cents, with late pricing equivalent to -60 cents, confirming the slack interest in the crude.
November Brent gained around 30 cents to $23.42 per barrel.
A Brent cargo loading on October 16-18 was sold at November Brent +13 cents, 11 cents over Wednesday's highest trade.

The buyer, which already held six cargoes, was short a cargo for a VLCC loading around October 15, possibly destined for South Africa, traders said. Its two other cargoes, loading around October 8, were probably destined for the United States.
"With heating oil making new highs in New York, its enough to bring warmth to refiners' hearts," a trader said.
He said there were still some end-month loadings of most North Sea crudes available, but Forties and Oseberg were both in short supply.
"Ekofisk is struggling a bit because of its high gasoline content," a refiner said.
Mediterranean sour crudes tumbled in line with Flotta in the North and with the sharp acceleration for sweet, traders said.
A Urals cargo changed hands at Dated Brent -70 cents cif Augusta on Wednesday, 10 cents below the last done, and dealers reported plenty more available.
A shipping inspector reported about 1.4 million tonnes due to load from the Black Sea by the end of next week.
"There's plenty there for whoever wants some. I think the next deal will have a seven in front of it," a trader said.
